author: Jo McCarroll
title: Flower power in Toowoomba
text:
JO MCCARROLL Last updated 05:00, September 26 2015 Larnie Nicolson Larnie Nicolson Larnie Nicolson Larnie Nicolson Larnie Nicolson Larnie Nicolson Larnie Nicolson Larnie Nicolson Larnie Nicolson Larnie Nicolson 
Bob and Val Ford wowed the crowds with a colourful mix of annuals, bulbs and perennials, native and exotic shrubs and a (truly extraordinarily) perfect lawn. They won Best Front Garden and Grand Champion in the Chronicle Garden Competition. 
Toowoomba Carnival of Flowers is famous for the colourful public floral displays. These two, in Queens Park in the central city, include pansies, petunias, antirrhinums, tulips, calendula and curly parsley. 
Around the World in Laurel Bank Park included flower beds representing 16 countries' flags. Parks staff grow more than 120,000 plants for the displays (then pray everything flowers on cue!) 
Wisteria in full bloom in Laurel Bank Park. 
The Mundey garden is packed with perennials, miniature conifers, tree ferns and maples. Owner Ben, in his 90s, still works in the garden every day. 
Ben and Mavis Mundey collected every rock in their garden, breaking them into pieces they could fit in their Holden. It took 131 trips. 
Gordon and Maria Reynolds used to run a native plant nursery and had a two acre garden before downsizing to 990m² in Toowoomba’s suburbs, but this garden is still full of Aussie natives to attract the birds they love. They also want gardeners to see you don’t sacrifice colour and flowers if you plant Aussie natives – grevilleas bloom for them almost year round. Maria says the more you prune them, the more flowers you get. 
Allan and Mary Kenna took top honours in the Heritage Bank Cottage Garden category with their backyard where brick-paved paths ramble through interplanted veges, herbs and perennial flowers. 
Tiny solar speakers are dotted among the crops at the Pure Land Learning College vege garden. They emit chants which, our guide told us, ensure the crops grow well and keep the worms happy! The veges grown are used to feed staff and students at this Buddhist school. 
A highlight of the Toowoomba Carnival of Flowers if the opening parade - this year a crowd of more than 100,000 gathered to watch. 1 of 10 « Previous « Previous Next » Next » 
Toowoomba's Carnival of Flowers is the longest running floral event in Australia, held over ten days every September and now in its 66th year. Here's NZ Gardener editor Jo McCarroll's pick of the flower displays in the city's parks, best private gardens open for the event and highlights from the opening Floral Parade. Ad Feedback Larnie Nicolson
